qas.question: What is a fundamental collection of documents of the Lutherans?
Beginning in what century was the Book of Concord a central part of the Lutheran Church?
What kind of statement is the Book of Concord?
What are the legislative systems of various Lutheran institutions called?
What kind of belief is the subject of the Book of Concord?
What is the fundamental collection of documents of the Catholic Church?
What book has been recognized as authoritative since the 1600s?
What book has not Orthodox beliefs?

context: <a0_0>The <b5_0><b6_0><b7_0>Book of Concord<b7_0/><b6_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/> is the historic doctrinal statement of the Lutheran Church, consisting of ten credal documents recognized as authoritative in Lutheranism since the <a1_0>16th<a1_0/> century. However, the Book of Concord is a <a2_0>confessional<a2_0/> document (stating <a4_0>orthodox<a4_0/> belief) rather than a book of ecclesiastical rules or discipline, like canon law. Each Lutheran national church establishes its own system of church order and discipline, though these are referred to as "<a3_0>canons<a3_0/>."
